response.answer_text: 5G holds the promise of creating a truly connected society with use cases ranging from immersive internet services, augmented reality and low-latency remote activities including highly advanced applications such as remote surgery. So, what exactly is 5G? If we base it on ITU standards, 5G requirements are as follows: 1)     Latency -Target for one-way latency between the radio network and the user equipment is 1ms 2)     Peak Data Rate – Peak data rate for an indoor environment is 20 Gbps 3)     Mobility – Wireless services experience of users should be maintained even at speeds of 500 km/hr, which could be the speed of a bullet train 4)     Connection Density – One million devices need to be supported per square kilometer area in a dense environment 5)     Area Traffic Capacity – In an area with large density of wireless devices, the supportable throughput needs to be 10 Mbps per square meter The below is what 5G will enable Internet of Things (IoT) – There are currently 5 billion connected devices in the world currently and there are forecasted to be 25 billion connected devices by 2020. It is really interesting to see the areas of focus for IoT. Although there are a lot of commercial applications, I want to focus on the consumer and what I see as applications the consumer can relate with the most. Connected Car – In Vehicle connectivity results in a slew of services that increases convenience for the consumer. Navigation, real time traffic information, nearby amenities, entertainment, vehicle diagnostics and emergency calls in case of accidents are all valuable services enhancing everyday life. Autonomous cars are the next step in this connected car future. Connected Healthcare – Connectivity can help doctors monitor care remotely. In the connected world of the future, remote surgeries could be performed with connected networks and robots. Connected Energy- The homes of today waste too much energy. With connected thermostats, consumers can control their energy use from their smart devices. The home of the future can have all appliances connected and monitored. If there are problems with the appliances, diagnostic information could be sent to the manufacturer to enable them to troubleshoot issues remotely and possibly fixed remotely. If the issues can’t be fixed remotely, the service technicians will know what parts to bring with them when they make the service call. Connected Wearables- Fitbit is a great demonstration of a connected wearable. The Apple watch and the Samsung gear are also great examples of what exists in the marketplace already in the arena of connected wearables. Smart glasses and connected clothing are just examples of what is being envisioned in the connected world of tomorrow. Connected Security- Home automation systems already exist which allow elements of the home to be remotely controlled like locking and unlocking doors and remotely viewing security cameras.

Here are the changes will we see with the implementation of 5g networks.  Image: Credit Broadband Internet EverywhereBroadband is currently defined by the FCC as an internet speed of 25 Mbps down and 3 Mbps up, which is an increase from the 4 Mbps and 1 Mbps defined in 2010. However, both are much slower than 5G speeds, which are expected to range anywhere from 300–1,000 Mbps, and even higher in some cases.Smart Vehicles, Cities, and FactoriesVehicles are pretty smart already, with smart car add-ons and built-in features like lights and wipers that turn on automatically, adaptive cruise, lane control, and even semi-autonomous driving. However, 5G will enable a quantum leap in car techno, still no flying cars, but many amazing changes are coming.Everything Is On-DemandWe could go on and on about other not-so-positive experiences with supposedly "on demand" online services. 5G, on the other hand, is built to minimize the delays your devices instantly. That cause these problems and provide a huge pipeline in which data can travel to reachImmersive AR and VRAugmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) are very bandwidth-demanding technologies, which 5G can handle with no problem. Immersive games played in AR and VR is one of the most talked about use cases for 5G, but that’s not all you can do with these reality-hacking technologies.Smarter HealthcareExchanging information with your doctor or an AI-powered system should be something you can tap into at any time, especially in emergency situations. An “on-demand doctor” is exactly where we’re headed with 5G. 5G's extremely low latency means that the surgery can take place in real time hundreds or even thousands of miles away.Another 5G medical transformation is in digital record keeping and file transfers. Many hospitals manage to keep digital health records without using 5G, but with improved speeds, machines in the whole building can move large sets of data much quicker.Better Law EnforcementPolice-operated drones also allow a city to deploy drones for regular monitoring of its citizens. Some see this as a dangerous invasion of privacy but the technology is already here and 5G will make it much more probable that drones will be deployed for this very reason.Peer-to-Peer (P2P) Communication5G is changing P2P connections because instead of just servers having access to quick upload speeds, your phone and computer can do the same. Every 5G cell has a minimum upload speed of 10 Gbps (1.25 gigabytes per second), meaning that in ideal conditions, users can transfer 1.25 GB of data every single second between devices. This is much faster than what's currently widely available. Hope the explanation helps, OKportal Technology

New wireless technology promises to make everything connected. Here’s a sample of what that could mean. As 100,000 people gathered in the Spanish city this week for the Mobile World Congress, the industry's annual conference, the next generation mobile network took center stage.  This is not just to do with its super-fast speeds, it's because 5G will create a ripple of developments that will change daily life. "5G is going to have a massive impact on people lives," says Laila Worrell, CEO of Altran North America, a high-tech engineering company. "We are going to see a big advance in quality of life that 5G can deliver for individuals."  For starters, there's the part it can play in your commute. Self-driving cars have been on the radar for a while, but with a 5G network they could become reality. Industry players claim 5G can be 100 times faster than 4G and that a huge number of devices will be able to connect to the network simultaneously. This will enable vehicles to talk to each other in real time: they'll know when another car is changing lanes or braking and can adjust to manage traffic accordingly. The BMW iNEXT, an electric SUV expected to come onto the market in 2021, is fitted with sensors that collect and process data from the car's surroundings. "This car is permanently surveying the road around it and sending relevant bits of information up to the cloud, generating a true real-time map that in turn is pushed down to all the other cars," Christoph Grote, senior vice-president of electronics at BMW, tells CNN's Samuel Burke.  "5G is good but 6G is better," says Ari Pouttu, a science professor at the University of Oulu, Finland. Expected to roll out in 2030, 6G will be a development beyond the smartphone. "Let's throw the smartphones away and think about how humans interact with infrastructure," says Poutto. "You can have smart surfaces with electronics in them, smart glasses so you can have devices everywhere." So, stay tuned and Like, share and comment.

This is another sensational headline, adding to the general IP hype. The text under the headline is completely ok, but if you hadn’t read the headline, would you still conclude from the text that 5G would change the world? Mobile communication has already changed the world, in the 1990s and 2000s, when first voice communication and then the internet became mobile. Those were the ground-breaking years. What we see since 10 years, and where 5G will not be any different, is an evolution. Neither 4G nor 5G have changed anything by themselves. It was the world that started to accelerate change, with the mobile technology fully available and, and using a mobile communication which became a commodity. Now during the 2010-years things have been driven by consumers and industry to a point where the 4G technology, standardized during 2008 - 2010 was foreseen to not be good enough for requested volumes, speeds and variety of applications fo the future. That’s where the International Telecommunication Union, Section Radio (in short: ITU-R) started to act and created a request for a new level of mobile communication - following the needs of society and industry. The key requests were more data speed, delivered essentially by higher bandwidthlower latencies, for industrial applicationsIOT Support, for example for smart city applicationsUltra-reliable connections available, for mission critical and security applicationsAnd that is precisely what we will see coming up during the next 5–6 years. Not there yet — in contradiction to the yelling marketing guys. So you see: it is the other way round: the world is changing, and it changes mobile communications with it. 5G is just a milestone of that development.

In the industrial field, 5G networks and big data platforms can connect many devices in the same area, so that various types of information can be transmitted and shared for data analysis and system management, thereby greatly reducing labor costs, improving work efficiency and production precision. Professionals believe that in the future, 5G will be the answer to many tech applications that 4G technology is unable to satisfy, such as automatic driving, mobile medical treatment and remote operation of complex mechanical equipment. "The 5G network has solved problems like video lag and remote control delay experienced under the 4G network, ensuring a nearly real-time operation. And you barely feel that the patient is 3,000 kilometers away." As 5G technology becomes more mature, its applications in the transportation, agriculture and healthcare industries are bound to flourish even more than the 4G era. It’s coming. But honestly since most of the US still doesn’t have 4G LTE, I as an engineering am VERY DUBIOUS about the 5G roll out. Note that where I live in upstate NY has ZERO cell coverage at all and I’m only 30 miles outside of Albany, the capital! On top of that the first round of 5G will be using an obsolete, energy-wasting modulation scheme because it was “easier” to use. This scheme consume 5x more power than the “final standard” will take. Of course, this means all currently installed 5G infrastructure will have to be replaced at considerable cost in just a few years. On top of that 5G requires 5x-15x the base station density of 4G/LTE. This begs two questions: what then is the energy efficiency and “greenness/carbon footprint” of the initial 5G roll out which is known to be power hungry? And now we’ll need 5x-15x MORE base stations than we even needed for 4G/LTE and for that we haven’t had the money, will or legal ability to establish full coverage even today! But magically it’s going to happen now with 5G where EVERY base station requires a fiber optic backhaul connection! You can start to see why I call bullshit on the rosy plans when my LTE connection on my iPhone disappears 5 minutes outside of Albany! And 3G disappears 30 seconds after that! Conservatively: 10–25 years with the realistic estimate for USA-wide complete coverage being 25 years if we are lucky. In urban cities you might see it in 5–10 years but only in the 10 largest cities of the US.

A 5G network is about a lot more than speed. That’s the “low hanging fruit” in building a 5G network, and it will be a benefit. There are two other areas where 5G is a marked improvement over 4G: “Massive Machine-type Communications”, or MMC. This is also known as the Internet of Things, or IoT. We don’t really know what this will be, as it’s up to entrepreneurs to exploit this capability. One example might be a lot more weather sensors that get data on microclimates.“Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communications”, or URLLC. This is even more of a challenge to see applications, as “ultra reliable” and “radio” don’t go together very well, due to a wide variety of reasons. But the radio connection is potentially substantially better than 4G, if the network is implemented well. The applications most often mentioned are gaming, autonomous vehicles, and remote surgery. I imagine that the real applications we’ll see will be something totally different!

5G - The next generation cellular technology that will provide faster and more reliable communication with ultra low latency. The peak network data speeds are expected to be in the range of 2-20 Gigabit per second (Gbps). South Korea and the U.S. became the first countries to commercially launch 5G services, in April 2019. India is yet to begin trial for these as the government is targeting 2020 as the launch year for 5G in the country. 5G technology will extend the use of wireless technologies — for the first time — across completely new sectors of the economy from industrial to commercial, educational, health care, agricultural, financial and social sectors. 5G is expected to form the backbone of emerging technologies such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and machine to machine communications, thereby supporting a much larger range of applications and services, including communication between driverless vehicles (self-driving cars), tele-surgery and real time data analytics. The ultra low latency offered by 5G makes the technology desirable for such use cases. Latency is the amount of time data takes to travel between its source and destination. With 5G technology, consumers will be able to download data heavy content such as 8K movies and games with better graphics in a few seconds of time, But once 5G becomes commercial, users will be required to change their current (4G) devices in favour of 5G-enabled ones.

There are so many promises about how faster 5G data will transform our lives, it sometimes feels mythical. Though lightning-fast download speeds are slowly coming to more carriers and phones, the prospects of self-driving cars talking to each other, remote surgery and 5G replacing your home Wi-Fi feel like the stuff of a still-distant future. But at last, we're finally starting to see a light at the end of the tunnel. Qualcomm, which makes the 5G chips and modems that every 5G phone in the US will rely on, shared a road map (scroll down to see the slides) that spells out when we might start seeing 5G improvements beyond just fast download speeds. Qualcomm isn't the only major 5G player, of course -- Huawei, Nokia and Ericsson are all leaders, too -- but Qualcomm's investments in 5G research and development mean that it has a strong hand in getting the next wave of 5G benefits off the ground. So, its timeline is a good place to start.

5G is the next (and fifth) generation of wireless technology systems. It will provide speeds faster than any previous generation, comparable to those delivered via fiber-optic cables. Early testing of this technology shows real-world speeds of 700-3000 Mbps (3 Gbps), which consumers may experience once 5G becomes commercially available. Movies that took minutes to download with 4G will take seconds with 5G. While smartphones and other mobile devices are the obvious use cases for 5G, there are many other applications for the technology. The internet of things (IoT), for example, will benefit tremendously from the speed and bandwidth provided by 5G, especially as the industry grows: Gartner estimates that over 20B IoT units will be installed by 2020, while IoT-related spending will reach nearly $3T. Autonomous vehicles, robotic surgery, and critical infrastructure monitoring are just a few of the potential applications of 5G-enabled IoT.

Hello, 5G communication is based on 3 main paradigms for future.These are Enhanced Mobile Broadband (EMBB), Ultra Reliable Low Latency Communication (URLLC) and Massive Machine Type Communication (MMTC). To fulfill these expectations 5G specifications are evolved with major changes in coding scheme for data and control, which is changed from Turbo to LDPC and Polar codes simultaneously. Which provides the efficient usage of bandwidth. The high data rate is achieved by using more efficient waveform for transmission, new concept of sub carrier spacing configurations and bandwidth part concept. The 3 different frequency used for 3 different applications which will provide IoT applications, voice connectivity and higher data rates. The change in waveform for transmission, sub-carrier spacing improve the latency from 20 milliseconds to 1 milliseconds. Hence, 5G will be revolution in the mobile telecommunication, which will improve the overall experience for every 5G mobile user.

Fifth generation wireless communications technology — “5G” — is, at heart, wireless networking that runs faster and carries more data than existing wireless technologies. What gets done with that capability depends on the system operators and equipment vendors. There are lots of details, and you’ll find plenty of marketing material to tell you how wonderful it will all be. I’m sure it will be pretty cool, and there will be lots of applications, but as for “changing everything”, I rather doubt it. Every new version of wireless has been touted as doing that. I get why the marketeers do it, but it’s just promotional hype. Expect incremental improvements — and expect to pay for them.  Question as posted: How will 5G change everything?

Well, it won’t change everything, but it could change a lot, but that will take time and innovation. 5G could enable communities that are currently digitally-adrift to be finally connected. It could connect many more “things” in places that were previously unconnected (see above) It could open up new business models and change the notion of a “mobile operator” There’s lots of things it could do, but many are technically feasible today, just not commercially feasible. The road to realising some of these “could dos” is long and costly, so don’t expect much beyond geographically restricted faster mobile phones and “broadband” in places you can’t get cables (aka FWA, fixed wireless access) in the near term.

5G will support peak data rate of 10 to 20Gbps, connectivity density one thousand to one million devices per square kms, reliability 99.999%, enhanced battery life for Internet of Things (IoT) devices 10 years, and latency 1 to 10ms.The future lies with millions of devices to enter in the market.
